subject: Communication
title: The Griots: West Africa's Living Libraries
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Griots: West Africa's Living Libraries usable.

hook.text: In West Africa, when a griot dies, they say it's like a library burning down. One person holds centuries of history.

buildup.text: Griots are oral historians, genealogists, and musicians who preserve community memory across generations.

discovery.text: They memorize lineages, treaties, and histories spanning hundreds of years ‚Äî without writing anything down.

twist.text: Alex Haley's 'Roots' was traced through a Gambian griot who recited Haley's ancestor's story from the 1700s.

climax.text: Griots prove that oral storytelling isn't primitive ‚Äî it's a sophisticated technology for cultural preservation.

punchline.text: Some libraries don't have shelves. They have voices.

quiz.question: What role do griots serve in West African culture?
